'''Katrina cough''' is a putative respiratory illness thought to be linked to exposure to [[mold]] and dust after the 2005 [[Hurricane Katrina]] in the [[United States]]. First described by doctors treating patients in the metro [[New Orleans]] area symptoms include [[cough]], [[paranasal sinus|sinus]] [[headache]], [[nasal congestion|congestion]], runny nose, and sore [[throat]], and [[conjunctivitis|pink eye]].<ref>[http://www.wwltv.com/topstories/stories/WWL103105katrinacough.170a5332.html "Mold, dust contributing to spread of 'Katrina cough,'" WWL-TV, November 1, 2005]</ref> This condition may make [[immunocompromised]] individuals more susceptible to bacterial [[bronchitis]] and [[sinusitis]]. Most patients are treated with [[antihistamine]]s, nasal sprays, and/or [[antibiotic]]s.
The Louisiana Office of Public Health conducted a [[case-control study]] of [[emergency department]] visits in New Orleans in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. The OPH distributed a questionnaire to patients seeking treatment for cough, sinus drip, sneezing, wheezing, chest congestion, swollen red and puffy eye(s) and sore throat. According to the study, state epidemiologists found no increase in the rate of New Orleans-area respiratory illnesses. Although rates were found to be no different in comparison to state and country rates, the study showed that people with chronic sinus or respiratory symptoms were more affected by the hurricane.
State epidemiologist Dr. Raoult Ratard disputed the existence of any disease cluster associated with the hurricane in 2006: "There is no such thing as a single condition such as ‘Katrina Cough’ that would be different from the bacterial and viral respiratory conditions we would expect to see at that time of year...no such outbreak occurred because of Hurricane Katrina."<ref>Bureau of Media & Communications. "Medical Study Shows No Increase in Respiratory Illnesses Because of Hurricane Katrina" ''[http://www.dhh.louisiana.gov/offices/news.asp?ID=192&Detail=852 Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals]''. April 18, 2006. URL accessed on 2006-05-16. [http://www.dhh.louisiana.gov/offices/publications/pubs-192/KatrinaCoughReport.pdf pdf]</ref>
Starting in 2008, Henry Glindmeyer, researcher and professor of pulmonary, critical care and environmental medicine at the [[Tulane University School of Medicine]] is conducting a five-year study to determine if workers in New Orleans face risks from inhalant exposure to minute particles such as mold, fungi or bacteria. The study is funded by the [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]], an agency of the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]], which is providing $1.86 million.<ref>[http://tulane.edu/news/newwave/010208_cough.cfm "Researcher Seeks Truth About 'Katrina Cough,'" ''New Wave'', Tulane University, January 2, 2008]</ref>
==See also== * [[Allergy]] * [[Coccidioidomycosis]]

[[File:Japanese kit Kat varieties.jpg|thumb|A variety of exclusive Japanese Kit Kat flavors on display in a store in [[Osaka]], Japan.]] There have been more than 300 limited-edition seasonal and regional flavors of [[Kit Kat]]s produced in [[Japan]] since 2000.<ref name="CNN Eatocracy">{{cite web|last1=Irvine|first1=Dean|title=How did Kit Kat become king of candy in Japan?|url=http://eatocracy.cnn.com/2012/02/02/how-did-kit-kat-became-king-of-candy-in-japan/?hpt=hp_bn8|website=Eatocracy at CNN|publisher=CNN|accessdate=10 February 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160208054752/http://eatocracy.cnn.com/2012/02/02/how-did-kit-kat-became-king-of-candy-in-japan/?hpt=hp_bn8|archivedate=8 February 2016|date=2 February 2012 |deadurl=No}}</ref><ref name="Telegraph 2015" /> [[Nestlé]], which operates the Kit Kat brand in Japan, reports that the brand overtook [[Meiji Seika|Meiji Chocolate]] as the top-selling confection in Japan from 2012 to 2014.<ref name="Nieburg">{{cite web|url=http://www.confectionerynews.com/Markets/Nestle-claims-chocolate-top-spot-over-Meiji-in-Japan|title=Nestle claims chocolate top spot over Meiji in Japan|website=Confectionerynews.com|last1=Nieburg|first1=Oliver|accessdate=10 February 2016}}</ref><ref name="DailyMailPizza" /> The company's marketing campaign, which partnered with [[Japan Post Service|Japan Post]] to sell the bar in 20,000 post offices, won an award in 2010.<ref name="AdAge">{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/global-news/marketing-nestle-flavors-kit-kat-japan-markets/142461/|title=Soy Sauce flavored Kit Kats? In Japan, they're number one|website=Ad Age|last1=Madden|first1=Normandy|accessdate=10 February 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114104513/http://adage.com/article/global-news/marketing-nestle-flavors-kit-kat-japan-markets/142461/|archivedate=14 January 2016}}{{subscription needed|via=[https://www.ebsco.com EBSCO]'s Academic Search Complete}}</ref> That campaign encouraged associations of the product's name to the [[False cognate|coincidental cognate]] {{nihongo|''Kitto Kattsu''|きっと勝つ}}, translated as "You will surely win",<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/travel/article/kitkat-shop-osaka-japan/index.html|title=Made-to-order KitKat store opens in Japan|date=2018-11-02|work=CNN Travel|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en}}</ref> and could be mailed as a [[good luck charm]] for students ahead of [[Entrance examination|university exams]].<ref name="Telegraph 2015" />
== History == [[File:キットカットに受験生向けメッセージ刻んであるんだが、なんかキツい (8358321632).jpg|thumb|A Japanese edition Kit Kat]] Kit Kats were introduced to Japan in [[1973 in Japan|1973]] when [[Rowntree's]] made an agreement with [[Fujiya]].<ref name="Telegraph 2015">{{cite web|last1=Demetriou|first1=Danielle|title=How the KitKat became a phenomenon in Japan|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/food-and-drink/features/how-the-kitkat-became-a-phenomenon-in-japan/|website=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=10 February 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151214022458/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/food-and-drink/features/how-the-kitkat-became-a-phenomenon-in-japan/|archivedate=14 December 2015|date=12 December 2015 |deadurl=No}}</ref> In 2014, they were the top-selling confection in the country.<ref name="AdAge" /> The Kit Kat brand took the number one sales position from Meiji chocolate in 2012, though Meiji remains the leading confection company in Japan overall.<ref name="Nieburg" />
In 2004, the green tea flavor was introduced.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/07/26/news/companies/flavored-kitkat-japan-nestle/index.html?sr=twmoney072617flavored-kitkat-japan-nestle1210PMVODtopLink&linkId=40208435|title=Nestlé is building a factory just for flavored KitKats|last=Iyengar|first=Rishi|date=26 July 2017|website=CNN|access-date=26 July 2017}}</ref> Since then, the product has been sold in more than 300 seasonal and regional flavors.<ref name="CNN Eatocracy" /><ref name="Telegraph 2015" /> The top-selling flavor of the candy bar in 2010 was [[soy sauce]].<ref name="AdAge" /> Nestlé attributes the success of the flavor varieties to the tradition of [[Souvenir|''omiyage'']], in which regional specialties are brought back for family and co-workers from trips away.<ref name="Guardian Gold">{{cite web|title=Nestle Japan strikes gold Kit Kat in single fingered salute to itself|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/nov/20/nestle-japan-strikes-gold-kitkat-in-single-fingered-salute-to-itself|website=Guardian|accessdate=10 February 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160120170401/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/nov/20/nestle-japan-strikes-gold-kitkat-in-single-fingered-salute-to-itself|archivedate=20 January 2016 |deadurl=No}}</ref> The company believes the limited-edition seasonal models create a "scarcity and rarity of value" for customers.<ref name="Madden-inv">{{cite news|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=a9h&AN=51525533&site=ehost-live|title=Break me off a piece of that soy-sauce bar|date=14 June 2010|publisher=Advertising Age|issue=24|last1=Madden|first1=Normandy|accessdate=10 February 2016}}{{subscription needed|via=[https://www.ebsco.com EBSCO]'s Academic Search Complete}}</ref>
The business model was created to solve a problem the company found in Japanese [[convenience store]]s, which frequently rotated items and flavors off of shelves. By producing smaller runs of flavors, the company was better able to control its production costs.<ref name="Madden-inv" /> It was also economically viable in Japan because there is no initial product fee for listing new products in Japanese convenience stores.<ref name="Madden-inv" />
Kit Kats in Japan are produced at Nestlé-owned factories in [[Himeji]] and [[Kasumigaura, Ibaraki|Kasumigaura]]. The milk chocolate used for Kit Kats is made from whole-milk powder and Nestlé buys most of its cacao beans from West Africa.<ref name=Rao>{{citation |last=Rao |first= Tejal |title=Big in Japan: the story of how Kit Kats became a booming business from Hokkaido to Tokyo and changed expectations about what a candy bar could be. | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 24, 2018|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/10/24/magazine/candy-kit-kat-japan.html}}</ref>
== Marketing == [[File:Santetsu 36-105 01.jpg|thumb|A train car with Kit Kat logos in Japan]] Marketing for Kit Kats in Japan is believed to have benefited from the coincidental [[false cognate]] with "Kitto Katsu", a phrase meaning "You will surely win" in Japanese.<ref name="Telegraph 2015" /> Some market research has shown that the brand is strongly correlated to good luck charms, particularly among students ahead of exams.<ref name="Telegraph 2015" /><ref name="Superstition">{{cite journal|last1=Vaidyanathan|first1=Rajiv|last2=Aggarwal|first2=Praveen|title=A Typology of Superstitious Behaviors: Implications for Marketing and Public Policy.|journal=Advances in Consumer Research – Latin American Conference Proceedings|date=2008|volume=2|pages=147–149|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=bth&AN=36211070&site=ehost-live|accessdate=10 February 2016|postscript={{subscription needed|via=[https://www.ebsco.com EBSCO]'s Academic Search Complete}}}}</ref><ref name="Ryall-Telegraph">{{cite news|last1=Ryall|first1=Julien|title=Exam fever gives Japan a craving for Kit Kat|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/1482614/Exam-fever-gives-Japan-a-craving-for-Kit-Kat.html|accessdate=10 February 2016|agency=The Telegraph|date=2 February 2005|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160107073246/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/1482614/Exam-fever-gives-Japan-a-craving-for-Kit-Kat.html|archivedate=7 January 2016}}</ref> Kit Kat's "Lucky Charm" advertising campaign in Japan won the Asian Brand Marketing Effectiveness Award in 2005.<ref name="Media">{{cite journal|title=Media: Asia's Media & Marketing Newspaper|journal=Media: Asia's Media & Marketing Newspaper|date=15 July 2005|page=39|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=bth&AN=17829957&site=ehost-live|accessdate=10 February 2016|publisher=Haymarket Business Publications Ltd|issn=1562-1138|postscript={{subscription needed|via=[https://www.ebsco.com EBSCO]'s Academic Search Complete}}}}</ref>
Nestlé and the Japan Post launched a campaign in 2009, allowing people to write messages and mail the chocolate bars from 20,000 post offices.<ref name="Telegraph 2015" /> The special packages included a space to write a message of encouragement and affix a stamp. The promotional packages were sold out within a month.<ref name="Saven">{{cite journal|last1=Saven|first1=Mandy|title=Hitting close to home: how a local identity enhances the packaging solution.|journal=Brand Packaging|date=1 October 2010|publisher=BNP Media|subscription= yes |via=[[HighBeam Research]] |accessdate= February 10, 2016 |url= https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-245113679.html}}</ref> That campaign won the Media Grand Prix in 2010's [[Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity|Cannes Lions]] International Advertising Festival.<ref name="AdAge" />
== Varieties == [[File:Kit Kat Strawberry with packaging.jpg|thumb|Japanese Strawberry Kit Kat bar]] The Kit Kat Chocolatory stores, with recipes designed by chef Yasumasa Takagi, opened in 2014, and had expanded to seven branches by 2015. The company claims it has served more than 1 million customers and earned more than 2 billion yen.<ref name="Telegraph 2015" /> These shops sell high-end Kit Kat products such as raspberry-infused dark chocolate, orange-chocolate rum, and [[Cherry blossom|''sakura'']] [[Matcha|green tea]].<ref name="Telegraph 2015" /> A variety of Takagi's flavors have been introduced as seasonal products, including flavors such as "plum, passion fruit and chilli, ginger and kinako soybean powder".<ref name="Telegraph 2015" /> In 2016, Nestlé introduced a [[sake]] Kit Kat, which combines sake powder with white chocolate.<ref name="SakeMcGee">{{cite web|last1=McGee|first1=Oona|title=Sake-flavored KitKat|url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/new-products/view/sake-flavored-kitkat|website=Japan Today|publisher=Japan Today|accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref>
Some varieties are restricted to a specific region associated with that particular bar.<ref name="AdAge" /> Others are limited-run varieties, with excess supply saved for year-end "[[Fukubukuro|happy bag]]" specials.<ref name="AdAge" /> In 2015, 500 single-finger bitter chocolate bars were sold with [[gold leaf]] wrapping for about $16 in high-end retail shops.<ref name="Guardian Gold" />
Notable varieties include [[Red bean paste|adzuki]] (red bean),<ref name="Telegraph 2015" /><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/japanese-kitkats-ii-23642|title=Japanese KitKats II|website=www.avclub.com|access-date=2016-03-13}}</ref> beni imo (purple sweet potato),<ref name="Telegraph 2015" /><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/japanese-kitkats-ii-23642|title=Japanese KitKats II|website=www.avclub.com|access-date=2016-03-13}}</ref> brown sugar syrup,<ref name="Telegraph 2015" /><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/japanese-kitkats-ii-23642|title=Japanese KitKats II|website=www.avclub.com|access-date=2016-03-13}}</ref> matcha (green tea),<ref name="Telegraph 2015" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/taste-test-japanese-kitkats-2296|title=Taste Test: Japanese KitKats|website=www.avclub.com|access-date=2016-03-13}}</ref> and soy sauce.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/taste-test-japanese-kitkats-2296|title=Taste Test: Japanese KitKats|website=www.avclub.com|access-date=2016-03-13}}</ref><ref name="NPR">{{cite web|last1=Neary|first1=Lynn|title=Kit Kat Kaleidoscope: Far-Out Flavors From Japan|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=126515207|website=NPR news|publisher=National Public Radio|accessdate=10 February 2016|date=14 May 2010}}</ref>
The cafe shop Pronto has introduced [[croissant]]s incorporating Kit Kats.<ref name="Telegraph 2015" /> Pizza chains Napoli no Kama and Strawberry Cones introduced dessert pizzas with bakeable Kit Kat toppings in March 2014.<ref name="DailyMailPizza">{{cite web|last1=Hall|first1=John|title=Have a break, have a Kit Kat PIZZA! Nestle Japan introduces new oven bake version of the 2-fingered classic and restaurants have used a bit of initiative|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2593441/Have-break-Kit-Kat-PIZZA-Nestle-Japan-introduces-new-oven-bake-version-2-fingered-classic-restaurants-used-bit-initiative.html|website=Daily Mail|accessdate=10 February 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150317172929/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2593441/Have-break-Kit-Kat-PIZZA-Nestle-Japan-introduces-new-oven-bake-version-2-fingered-classic-restaurants-used-bit-initiative.html|archivedate=17 March 2015}}</ref>
In October 2018, Nestle opened a Kit Kat store at [[Namba Station]], in the Chuo ward of [[Osaka]], on Japan's [[Honshu Island|Honshu island]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/travel/article/kitkat-shop-osaka-japan/index.html|title=Made-to-order KitKat store opens in Japan|date=2018-11-02|work=CNN Travel|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Larry Dossey | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_place = [[Groesbeck, Texas]]<ref name=bplace>{{cite book|last=Marohn|first=Stephanie|title=Audacious Aging|year=2009|publisher=Elite Books|isbn=978-1-60070-061-3|page=108}}</ref> | birth_date = 1940<ref name=viafdossey>[http://viaf.org/viaf/44408408/ Larry Dossey at VIAF]</ref> | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = | occupation = Alternative-medicine advocate, public speaker, writer, physician | salary = | title = | spouse = | parents = | brother = | children = | nationality = [[United States]] | ethnicity = | website = {{URL|http://larrydosseymd.com}} }}
'''Larry Dossey''' (born 1940,<ref name=viafdossey/> [[Groesbeck, Texas]]<ref name=bplace/>) is a physician and author who propounds the importance for [[healing]] of [[prayer]], [[spirituality]], and other non-physical factors.
==Biography== According to his written biography on his personal website,<ref name=ldsite>[http://www.dosseydossey.com/larry/default.html Larry Dossey (biography)] (accessed 4 September 2015)</ref> Dossey graduated from [[University of Texas at Austin]] and received an M.D. from [[University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center]] in Dallas (1967).<ref name=ldsite/> Dossey served as a battalion surgeon in Vietnam, being decorated for valor, and served as Chief of Staff of [[Medical City Dallas Hospital]] (1982).<ref name=ldsite/>
==Reception== Dossey's writings and opinions have been controversial, having drawn both praise and criticism.<!--- THIS SIMPLE STATEMENT THAT HE HAS "drawn both praise and criticism", IS EASILY "EXTRACTABLE" FROM THE REACTIONS. GOING FURTHER TO SAY SOMETHING MORE NUANCED RISKS ENGAGING IN ORIGINAL RESEARCH. BALANCED SECONDARY SOURCES WOULD BE DESIRABLE THAT CHARACTERIZE THE TYPES OF PRO AND CON REACTIONS--->
Surgical oncologist [[David Gorski]] has written that Dossey utilizes [[straw man]] arguments, misrepresents and misunderstands [[medical research]] and "the evidence base in favor of the woo that Dr. Dossey favors is pathetic in comparison to that supporting science-based medicine."<ref>[https://www.sciencebasedmedicine.org/be-careful-what-you-ask-for-larry-dossey-deepak-chopra-and-rustum-roy-declare-war-on-science-based-medicine/ "Be careful what you wish for, Dr. Dossey, you just might get it"]. Science-Based Medicine. Retrieved 6 September 2015.</ref> In 2010 Dossey co-wrote a post in the [[Huffington Post]] called "The Mythology Of Science-Based Medicine" with [[Deepak Chopra]] and [[Rustum Roy]], which Gorski characterized as "an exercise that combines cherry-picking, logical fallacies, and whining, raising the last of these almost to an art form."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gorski|first1=David|title=Be careful what you wish for, Dr. Dossey, you just might get it|url=https://sciencebasedmedicine.org/be-careful-what-you-ask-for-larry-dossey-deepak-chopra-and-rustum-roy-declare-war-on-science-based-medicine/|work=Science-Based Medicine|date=11 January 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Dossey|first1=Larry|last2=Chopra|first2=Deepak|last3=Roy|first3=Rustum|title=The Mythology Of Science-Based Medicine|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/dr-larry-dossey/the-mythology-of-science_b_412475.html|work=The Huffington Post|date=18 March 2010}}</ref>
Gary P. Posner, a physician, has criticized Dossey for writing "New Age psychobabble". Posner in a review has stated that Dossey uncritically accepts psychic powers, [[parapsychology]] experiments and dubious claims such as [[wikt:voodoo|voodoo]] or "[[distant healing]]" as genuine, whilst ignoring the literature that has refuted these subjects.<ref>[http://www.gpposner.com/Healing_Words.html "Medical Practice Enters a New Age"]. Originally published in the Summer 1994 Skeptical Inquirer and in the Summer 1994 Tampa Bay Skeptics Report. Retrieved 6 September 2015.</ref>
Psychologist [[Robert A. Baker]] in a review for Dossey's ''Healing Words'' wrote that it is an entertaining book but "We'd all be better served-Dossey, his patients, his readers, and the general public-if Dossey would take his head out of the clouds, plant his feet on the ground, and stop talking nonsense. Everyone knows that evil looks won’t kill you. We also know that sticks and stones will break your bones and a doctor’s words alone-no matter how kind or gentle-will never heal you."<ref>[http://www.csicop.org/sb/show/if_looks_could_kill_and_words_could_heal/ "If Looks Could Kill and Words Could Heal"]. Skeptical Inquirer. Retrieved 6 September 2015.</ref>
John Roberts in the ''[[BMJ|British Medical Journal]]'' has described ''Healing Words'' as a religious book, useful to see how an argument could be made on how humans could utilize prayer to heal but some of the book was "convoluted new-age jargon".<ref>Roberts, John. (1995). ''Healing Words: The Power Of Prayer And The Practice Of Medicine by Larry Dossey''. [[BMJ|British Medical Journal]]. Vol. 311, No. 7013. p. 1174.</ref>
Dossey's views and activities have frequently been reported in the media. For example, ''[[Business Insider]]'' quoted Dossey as having "coined the term 'time-sickness' in 1982 to describe the belief that 'time is getting away, that there isn’t enough of it, and that you must pedal faster and faster to keep up.'"<ref name=businessinsider2015>{{cite news |last1=Parrish |first1=Shane |title=The modern workplace is ruining the way we think |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/the-modern-workplace-is-ruining-the-way-we-think-2015-8 |accessdate=5 September 2015 |work=[[Business Insider]] |date=20 August 2015}}</ref>
The ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]'' described Dossey as a "distinguished American physician" and a "New York Times best-selling author", while quoting his views on [[Lorna Byrne]].<ref name=belfasttelegraph2015>{{cite news|last1=Brankin|first1=Una|title=Mum can be difficult to get organised... she gets so distracted by angels|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/life/features/mum-can-be-difficult-to-get-organised-she-gets-so-distracted-by-angels-31222778.html|accessdate=5 September 2015|work=[[Belfast Telegraph]]|date=16 May 2015}}</ref> The Minnesota ''[[Star Tribune]]'' reported that in 1993, Dossey had appeared on the [[Oprah Winfrey]] show, in an episode themed on the power of prayer, describing Dossey as "a physician who advocates for spirituality in health care".<ref name="startribune2014">{{cite news |last1=Pratt |first1=Anna |title='Make every day count': Words that a cancer survivor lives by |url=http://www.startribune.com/make-every-day-count-words-that-a-cancer-survivor-lives-by/261709521/ |accessdate=5 September 2015 |work=[[Star Tribune]] (Minnesota) |date=3 June 2014}}</ref>
The "Jacket Copy" blog of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' interviewed Dossey and quoted him extensively when reviewing one of his books.<ref name=latimes2009>{{cite news|last1=Jacket Copy (regular LAT column)|title=Dr. Larry Dossey and your internal crystal ball|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/jacketcopy/2009/05/power-of-premonitions.html |accessdate=5 September 2015 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=1 May 2009}}</ref>
==Selected works==
*{{cite book|last1=Dossey|first1=Larry|title=Healing words : the power of prayer and the practice of medicine|date=1993|publisher=HarperSanFrancisco|location=[San Francisco, Calif.]|isbn=0062502514|edition=1st}} *{{cite book|last1=Dossey|first1=Larry|title=Prayer is good medicine : how to reap the healing benefits of prayer|date=1997|publisher=HarperSanFrancisco|location=San Francisco, Calif.|isbn=0062514237|edition=1st}} *{{cite book |last1=Dossey|first1=Larry |last2=Capra|first2=Fritjof (foreword) |authorlink2=Fritjof Capra |title=Space, time, & medicine |date=1982 |publisher=Shambhala |location=Boulder|isbn=0877732248}} * Dossey, Larry, (1982) One Mind: How Our Individual Mind is Part of a Greater Consciousness and Why It Matters, 2013, Carlsbad, Calif, Hay House. {{ISBN|978-1-4019-4377-6}} *{{Cite book|title=One Mind: How Our Individual Mind Is Part of a Greater Consciousness and Why It Matters|last=Dossey|first=Larry|publisher=Hay House|year=2013|isbn=1401943772 }} *{{Cite book|title=The Power of Premonitions: How Knowing the Future Can Shape Our Lives|last=Dossey|first=Larry|publisher=Dutton|year=2009|isbn=0525951164}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{official|http://www.dosseydossey.com/larry/default.html}}

page.title: Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare

revision.text:
{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare |nativename = 厚生労働省 |nativename_a = |nativename_r = Kōsei-rōdō-shō |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = Go-shichi_no_kiri_crest.svg |seal_width = 100px |seal_caption = |picture = GovernmentOfficeComplexNo5.jpg |picture_width = 250px |picture_caption = |formed = {{start date|2001||}} |date1 = |date1_name = |date2 = |date2_name = |preceding1 = {{nihongo|Ministry of Health and Welfare|厚生省|Kōsei-shō}} |preceding2 = {{nihongo|Ministry of Labour|労働省|Rōdō-shō}} |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Japan]] |headquarters = 1-2-2 [[Kasumigaseki]], [[Chiyoda, Tokyo|Chiyoda-ku]], [[Tokyo]], 100-8916 Japan |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = [[Takumi Nemoto]], Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare |minister2_name = [[Yoshinori Oguchi]], State Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare |minister3_name = [[Emiko Takagai]], State Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare |parent_agency = [[Government of Japan]] |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = http://www.mhlw.go.jp |footnotes = }}
The {{Nihongo|'''Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare'''|厚生労働省|Kōsei-rōdō-shō}} is a [[Cabinet (government)|cabinet]] level ministry of the [[Government of Japan|Japanese government]]. It is commonly known as {{Nihongo|''Kōrō-shō''|厚労省}} in Japan. The ministry provides regulations on maximum residue limits for agricultural chemicals in foods, basic food and drug regulations, standards for foods, food additives, etc.
It was formed with the merger of the former Ministry of Health and Welfare or {{Nihongo|''Kōsei-shō''|厚生省}} and the Ministry of Labour or {{Nihongo|''Rōdō-shō''|労働省}}.
The Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare is a member of the [[Cabinet of Japan|Cabinet]] and is chosen by the [[Prime Minister of Japan|Prime Minister]], typically from among members of the [[National Diet|Diet]].
==Organization== The ministry contains the following sections: * The Minister's Secretariat (including the Statistics and Information Department) * The Health Policy Bureau * The Health Service Bureau * Pharmaceutical and Food Safety Bureau (including the Food Safety Department) * The [[Labor Standards Bureau]] (including the Industrial Safety and Health Department, Workers Compensation Department, and Workers' Life Department) * The Employment Security Bureau (including the Employment Measures for the Elderly and Persons with Disabilities Department) * The Human Resources Development Bureau * The Equal Employment, Children and Families Bureau * The Social Welfare and War Victims' Relief Bureau (including the Department of Health and Welfare for People with Disabilities) * The Health and Welfare Bureau for the Elderly * The Health Insurance Bureau * The Pension Bureau * The Director-General for Policy Planning and Evaluation * Affiliated research institutions (6 research institutes, 218 national hospitals, 13 quarantine stations, and 3 Social Welfare Facilities) * Councils (Social Security Council, Health Sciences Council, Labour Policy Council, Medical Ethics Council, Pharmaceutical Affairs and Food Sanitation Council, Evaluation Committee for Independent Administrative institutions, Central Minimum Wages Council, Labour Insurance Appeal Committee, Central Social Insurance Medical Council, Examination Committee of Social Insurance, Examination Committee for Certification of Sickness and Disability, Examination Committee for Relief Assistances) * Regional Bureaus (8 Regional Bureaus of Health and Welfare and 47 Prefectural Labour Bureaus) * External Bureaus ([[Japan Pension Service]], [[Labour Relations Commission|Central Labor Relations Commission]])<ref>Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare website [http://www.mhlw.go.jp/english/org/detail/index.html Organization of the Ministry of Health, Labor, and Welfare] Retrieved on November 23rd 2010</ref>
==Investigations==
===Highway tour bus companies=== After a fatal bus accident on April 29, 2012, where a bus bound for [[Tokyo Disneyland]] crashed in [[Gunma Prefecture]] killing seven and injuring 39 others,<ref>The Japan Times [http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120430a1.html Bus crash in Gunma leaves seven dead, 39 injured April 30 2012] Retrieved on July 27, 2012</ref> the ministry launched an investigation into highway bus companies. Investigations were carried out at a total of 339 businesses. It was discovered that 95.6% (324 firms) were violating the [[Labor Standards Act of 1947|Labor Standards Law]] and the Industrial Safety and Health Law. 219 businesses (64.6%) broke the law by having their drivers work behind the wheel more than the legal maximum of eight hours a day and 40 hours a week, or longer than what was agreed upon with their [[Labor unions in Japan|labor union]]. It also found 37 businesses, (10.9%), did not provide "at least one day off a week," which the law obliges employers to give their drivers. Also, it found that 260 (76.6%) did not observe standards involving bus driver working hours, which prohibit them from working more than 16 hours a day in combined driving and office time. The ministry said it took "corrective measures" with those who violated the laws.<ref>The Yomiuri Shimbun [http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T120719004995.htm 80% of tour bus firms found to violate laws July 20 2012] Retrieved on July 27, 2012</ref>
==Criticism== Published ministry employee and outspoken critic Moriyo Kimura states that the ministry's medical officers (''ikei gikan'') are "corrupt and self-serving." Kimura states that the officers, who number 250, have little experience and see no patients nor practice medicine after being hired by the ministry. Thus, says Kimura, Japan's public health policies lag behind other developed countries, by "decades".<ref>Otake, Tomoko, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/life/2009/11/01/general/ministry-insider-speaks-out/ Ministry insider speaks out]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', November 1, 2009, p. 10.</ref>
==See also== * [[European Medicines Agency]] * [[International Conference on Harmonisation of Technical Requirements for Registration of Pharmaceuticals for Human Use]] * [[Drug development]] * [[Clinical trial]] * [[U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.mhlw.go.jp/english/index.html Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=January 2016}} '''Molecular modification''' is chemical alteration of a known and previously characterized [[lead compound]] for the purpose of enhancing its usefulness as a [[drug]]. This could mean enhancing its specificity for a particular body target site, increasing its [[Potency (pharmacology)|potency]], improving its rate and extent of [[absorption (pharmacokinetics)|absorption]], modifying to advantage its time course in the body, reducing its [[toxicity]], changing its [[physical property|physical]] or [[chemical property|chemical properties]] (like [[solubility]]) to provide desired features.
==Modification for water solubility== Molecular modification is used to enhance drug’s water solubility by incorporating water solubilizing groups in its structure. The discussion of the introduction of water solubilizing groups into the structure of a lead compound can be conveniently broken down into four general areas:
* The type of group introduced; * Whether the introduction is reversible or irreversible; * The position of incorporation; and * The chemical route of introduction.
===The type of group=== The incorporation of [[Chemical polarity|polar]] [[functional group]]s, such as the [[alcohol]], [[amine]], [[amide]], [[carboxylic acid]], [[sulfonic acid]] and [[phosphate]] groups, which either ionize or are capable of relatively strong intermolecular forces of attraction with water ([[hydrogen bond]]ing), will usually result in analogues with an increased water solubility. Acidic and basic groups are particularly useful, since these groups can be used to form salts, which would give a wider range of dosage forms for the final product. However, the formation of zwitterions by the introduction of either an acid group into a structure containing a base or a base group into a structure containing an acid group can reduce water solubility. Introduction of weakly polar groups, such as [[carboxylic acid ester]]s, [[aryl halide]]s and [[alkyl halide]]s, will not significantly improve water solubility and can result in enhanced lipid solubility.
The incorporation of acidic residues into a lead structure is less likely to change the type of activity, but it can result in the analogue exhibiting [[hemolysis|haemolytic]] properties. Furthermore, the introduction of an [[aromatic]] acid group usually results in [[anti-inflammatory]] activity, whilst carboxylic acids with an alpha functional group may act as chelating agents. Basic water solubilizing groups have a tendency to change the mode of action, since bases often interfere with neurotransmitters and biological processes involving amines. However, their incorporation does mean that the analogue can be formulated as a wide variety of acid salts. Non-ionizable groups do not have the disadvantages of acidic and basic groups.
===Reversibly and irreversibly attached groups=== The type of group selected also depends on the degree of permanency required. Groups that are bound directly to the carbon skeleton of the lead compound by less reactive C–C, C–O and C–N bonds are likely to be irreversibly attached to the lead structure.
Groups that are linked to the lead by ester, amide, phosphate, sulfate and glycosidic bonds are more likely to be [[metabolism|metabolized]] from the resulting analogue to reform the parent lead compound as the analogue is transferred from its point of administration to its site of action. Compounds with this type of solubilizing group are acting as prodrugs and so their activity is more likely to be the same as the parent lead compound. However, the rate of loss of the solubilizing group will depend on the nature of the transfer route, and this could affect the activity of the drug.
===The position of the water solubilizing group=== In order to preserve the type of activity exhibited by the [[lead compound]], the water solubilizing group should be attached to a part of the structure that is not involved in the drug–receptor interaction. Consequently, the route used to introduce a new water solubilizing group and its position in the lead structure will depend on the relative reactivities of the pharmacophore and the rest of the molecule. The reagents used to introduce the new water solubilizing group should be chosen on the basis that they do not react with, or in close proximity to, the pharmacophore. This will reduce the possibility of the new group affecting the relevant drug–receptor interactions.
===Methods of introduction=== Water solubilizing groups are best introduced at the beginning of a drug [[chemical synthesis|synthesis]], although they may be introduced at any stage. Introduction at the beginning avoids the problem of a later introduction changing the type and/or nature of the drug–receptor interaction. A wide variety of routes may be used to introduce a water solubilizing group; the one selected will depend on the type of group being introduced and the chemical nature of the target structure. Many of these routes require the use of protecting agents to prevent unwanted reactions of either the water solubilizing group or the lead structure.
===Acidic and basic groups=== Examples of water solubilizing structures and the routes used to introduce them into the lead structures. O-alkylation, N-alkylation, O-acylation and N-acylation reactions are used to introduce both acidic and basic groups. [[Acetylation]] methods use both the appropriate [[acid chloride]] and [[anhydride]].
Examples of water solubilizing structures and the routes used to introduce them into lead structures. Phosphate acid halides have been used to introduce phosphate groups into lead structures. Structures containing hydroxy groups have been introduced by reaction of the corresponding monochlorinated hydrin and the use of suitable epoxides amongst other methods. Sulphonic acid groups may be introduced by either direct sulfonation or the addition of bisulfite to reactive C = C bonds amongst other methods.
==References== *{{cite book|author1=S. N. Pandeya|author2=J. R. Dimmock|title=An Introduction to Drug Design|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d5MWr1WNNg0C&pg=PA27|year=1997|publisher=New Age International|isbn=978-81-224-0943-7|pages=27}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Molecular Modification}} [[Category:Pharmaceutical sciences]]

The '''National Council for Homeopathy''' ('''NCH''') is an autonomous body constituted to regulate the education and registration of [[homeopathic]] medical practitioners in Pakistan.<ref>{{cite book|title=WHO Global Atlas of Traditional, Complementary and Alternative Medicine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VO8K9h9GvaoC&pg=PA167|year=2005|publisher=World Health Organization|isbn=978-92-4-156286-7|page=167}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Educational Directory of Pakistan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZzrjAAAAMAAJ|year=1995|page=322|publisher=Ibrahim Publishers}}</ref> Based in [[Rawalpindi]], the council was formed in 1965, when homeopathic system of medicine was recognized by the [[Government of Pakistan]] under the Unani, Ayurvedic and Homeopathic Practitioners Act, 1965.<ref name="Pakchem 01">{{cite web|title=National Council for Homeopathy|url=http://www.pakchem.net/2012/04/national-council-for-homoeopathy.html}}</ref><ref name="NCH 65">{{cite web|title=National Council for Homeopathy|url=http://nchpakistan.gov.pk|publisher=NCH Pakistan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://nasirlawsite.com/laws/uahpa.htm | title = The Unani, Ayurvedic and Homoeopathic Practitioners Act, 1965}}</ref>
==Overview== The council consisted of 21 members. Four members, being registered [[homeopaths]], are nominated by the provincial government, one from each province eleven members are elected from among the registered and listed homeopaths, two members are elected from among themselves by the teachers of recognized homeopathy institutions and four members are nominated by the Federal Government, of whom one a scientist from the related field and one Deputy Secretary (Budget), [[Ministry of National Health Services, Regulation and Coordination]].
The election of members are held after five years on provincial basis by direct balloting system. All registered homeopathic practitioners cast their votes for all seats of their related province.<ref name="NCH 65"/> The council accredits and registers the four year Diploma in Homeopathic Medicine and Surgery (D.H.M.S.) and the five year [[Bachelor of Homeopathic Medicine and Surgery]] (B.H.M.S.) degree programs by different colleges and universities throughout Pakistan.
== See also == *[[Homeopathy]] *[[List of medical organizations in Pakistan]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://nchpakistan.gov.pk/ Official website]
[[Category:Medical and health organisations based in Pakistan]] [[Category:1965 establishments in Pakistan]] [[Category:Government agencies established in 1965]] [[Category:Organisations based in Punjab, Pakistan]] [[Category:Professional associations based in Pakistan]] [[Category:Homeopathic education]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} [[File:NationalDoughnutDay.jpg|thumb|Salvation Army volunteers traveled overseas to set up service huts located in abandoned buildings near the front lines where they could serve baked goods]]
'''National Doughnut Day''', or '''National Donut Day''' — celebrated in the United States, is on the first Friday of June of each year, succeeding the Doughnut event created by [[The Salvation Army]] in [[Chicago]] in 1938 to honor those of their members who served doughnuts to soldiers during [[World War I]].<ref name="Holey holiday">Kevin Fagan [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/06/06/BAEQ181KO9.DTL A holey holiday – National Donut Day] February 31, 2009 SF Chronicle</ref> The holiday celebrates the [[doughnut]]. Many American doughnut stores offer free doughnuts on National Doughnut Day.<ref name="lamarsDonutDay">{{cite web |url=http://www.lamars.com/ai1ec_event/free-donuts-on-national-donut-day/?instance_id=69 |title=LaMar’s Donuts Celebrates National Donut Day With Free Donut |accessdate=May 29, 2011 |publisher=LaMar's Donuts & Coffee shop}}</ref><ref name="LATimesDonutDayKKreme">{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/dailydish/2009/06/national-doughnut-day-corkbar-test-kitchen-tuesdays.html |title=Small Bits: Test Kitchen Tuesdays at Corkbar and National Donut Day |accessdate=June 4, 2009 |work=Los Angeles Times |author=Elina Shatkin | date=June 2, 2009}}</ref><ref name="bostonGlobeDonutDay">{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/business/ticker/2009/06/dunkin_buy_joe.html |title=Dunkin': Buy joe, get free Donut Day sinker |accessdate=June 4, 2009 |publisher=The Boston Globe |author=Chris Reidy, Globe staff |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103150235/http://www.boston.com/business/ticker/2009/06/dunkin_buy_joe.html |archivedate=2012-11-03 |date=June 4, 2009}}</ref><ref name="eatonDonutDay">{{cite web |url=http://hamptonroads.com/2009/06/krispy-kreme-donuts-free-tomorrow |title=Krispy Kreme Donuts – Free tomorrow! |accessdate=June 4, 2009 |publisher=The Virginian-Pilot: HamptonRoads.com |author=Lorraine Eaton |date=June 4, 2009}}</ref>
==History== National Doughnut Day started in 1938<ref name="Holey holiday" /> as a fund raiser for [[Chicago]]'s [[The Salvation Army]]. Their goal was to help those in need during the [[Great Depression]], and to honor The Salvation Army "Lassies" of World War I, who served doughnuts to soldiers.
Soon after the US entrance into [[World War I]] in 1917, The Salvation Army sent a fact-finding mission to France. The mission concluded that the needs of US enlisted men could be met by canteens/social centers termed "huts" that could serve baked goods, provide writing supplies and stamps, and provide a clothes-mending service. Typically, six staff members per hut would include four female volunteers who could "mother" the boys. These huts were established by The Salvation Army in the United States near army training centers.
About 250 Salvation Army volunteers went to France. Because of the difficulties of providing freshly baked goods from huts established in abandoned buildings near to the front lines, the two Salvation Army volunteers (Ensign [[Margaret Sheldon]] and Adjutant [[Helen Purviance]]) came up with the idea of providing doughnuts. These are reported to have been an "instant hit", and "soon many soldiers were visiting The Salvation Army huts". Margaret Sheldon wrote of one busy day: "Today I made 22 pies, 300 doughnuts, 700 cups of coffee."
Soon, the women who did this work became known by the servicemen as "Doughnut Girls".<ref name="Doughboy Center">{{cite web |url=http://www.worldwar1.com/dbc/doughnut.htm |title=Doughboy Center – The Story of the American Expeditionary Forces |author=Susan Mitchem, Director of the Archives at Salvation Army Headquarters}}</ref>
[[File:Doughnut Dollies 1918 France.jpg|Doughnut Dollies 1918 France.jpg|right|thumb|Doughnut Dollies were women volunteers of the Salvation Army, who traveled to France in 1918 to support US soldiers]]
A misconception has taken hold that the provision of doughnuts to US enlisted men in World War I is the origin of the term "[[doughboy]]" to describe US infantry. But, the term was in use as early as the [[Mexican–American War]] of 1846–47.{{Citation needed |reason=No source provided that says term originated during Mexican-American War era, nor is it mentioned in said article. The Doughboy article similarly needs better citation (see Doughboy Talk page). During WWI, "doughboys" refers to the apparent wealth of U.S. soldiers newly joining the war; dough being a euphemism for money. |date=June 2012}}
In Chicago and other cities, National Doughnut Day is still a fundraiser for The Salvation Army. In 2017, the organization joined with Russ's Market, Super Saver, LaMar's Donuts, Hurts Donut and [[Krispy Kreme]] in [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] and [[Tempe, Arizona]] to raise funds on National Doughnut Day.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://journalstar.com/news/local/local-bakeries-offer-free-or-cheap-doughnuts-friday/article_1772f924-e0df-5e24-84af-ebd9a9fd53ca.html|title=Local bakeries offer free or cheap doughnuts Friday|last=Star|first=Lincoln Journal|work=JournalStar.com|access-date=2017-06-01|language=en}}</ref>
In the Second World War, Red Cross Volunteers also distributed doughnuts, and it became routine to refer to the Red Cross girls as Doughnut Dollies as well.
There are three other doughnut holidays, the origins of which are obscure. International Jelly-Filled Doughnut Day is widely recognized as June 8 (occasionally as June 9).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://foodimentary.com/2016/06/08/june-8-is-national-jelly-filled-doughnut-day/|title=June 8th is National Jelly-Filled Donut Day|date=2016-06-08|website=Foodimentary – National Food Holidays|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref> National Cream-Filled Doughnut Day is celebrated on September 14<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.punchbowl.com/holidays/national-cream-filled-donut-day|title=National Cream Filled Donut Day|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref> although there is also a National Boston Cream Pie Day observed October 23rd.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nationaldaycalendar.com/national-boston-cream-pie-day-october-23/|title=NATIONAL BOSTON CREAM PIE DAY|access-date=2017-10-29}}</ref> Buy a Doughnut Day occurs on October 30.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cdkitchen.com/recipes/articles/view/310/1/Buy-a-Doughnut-Day.html|title=Buy a Doughnut Day – Fun Food Holiday {{!}} CDKitchen|website=CDKitchen|language=en|access-date=2017-06-01}}</ref>
The birthday of the [[United States Marine Corps]] was once referred to as National Donut Day, in a successful ruse by American prisoners of war at [[Son Tay prison camp]] to trick the North Vietnamese into giving out donuts in honor of the occasion.<ref name=USMC-Donut-Day>{{cite web|title=Today is National Donut Day: A funny POW story|url=http://blog.usni.org/2009/11/10/today-is-national-donut-day-a-funny-pow-story|work=November 10, 2009|publisher=US Naval Institute|accessdate=November 9, 2012}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of food days]] * [[List of doughnut varieties]] *{{portal-inline|Food}}
==Notes and references== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== * Those Extraordinary Women of World War I, Karen Zeinert, 2001 * [http://www.worldwar1.com/dbc/origindb.htm Origins of "Doughboy", An Interim Report], by Michael E. Hanlon, June 16, 2003 * [http://holidayinsights.com/moreholidays/June/doughnutday.htm Holiday Insights : National Doughnut Day, or National Donut Day]
==External links== * [http://donutdayusa.com National Donut Day Website and Resources] {{Doughnuts}} {{US Holidays}}
[[Category:Doughnuts]] [[Category:Unofficial observances]] [[Category:June observances]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 1938]] [[Category:Observances about food and drink]] [[Category:Holidays and observances by scheduling (nth weekday of the month)]]

{{refimprove|date=November 2017}} '''Nose-blowing''' is the act of expelling nasal [[mucus]] by [[exhaling]] forcefully through the [[Human nose|nose]], usually into a [[facial tissue]] or [[handkerchief]]. In some cultures, blowing one's nose in public may be considered a breach of [[etiquette]].
[[File:Sneeze_in_white_hankie.jpg|thumb|Woman blowing her nose]]
Nose-blowing may be used to alleviate [[nasal congestion]] or [[rhinorrhea]] (runny nose). A 2000 study showed that nose-blowing produces a high degree of pressure in the nasal cavities and may worsen a [[Common cold|cold]] by propelling nasal mucus into the [[paranasal sinuses]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Nose blowing propels nasal fluid into the paranasal sinuses |last=Gwaltney |first=JM Jr. |last2=Hendley |first2=JO |last3=Phillips |first3=CD |last4=Bass |first4=CR |last5=Mygind |first5=N |last6=Winther |first6=B |work=[[Clinical Infectious Diseases]] |date=February 2000 |volume=30 |issue=2 |pages=387–91}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Nose-picking]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Rhinology]] [[Category:Sneeze]]
{{medical-stub}}

Detection of [[peroxide]] gives the initial evidence of [[rancidity]] in unsaturated fats and oils. Other methods are available, but '''peroxide value''' is the most widely used. It gives a measure of the extent to which an oil sample has undergone primary oxidation, extent of secondary oxidation may be determined from p-anisidine test.<ref>Chemistry And Technology Of Oils And Fats [http://www.alliedpublishers.com/BookDetails.aspx?BookId=228 Chemistry And Technology Of Oils And Fats By Dr. M.M. Chakrabarty]</ref>
The [[double bond]]s found in fats and oils play a role in [[autoxidation]]. Oils with a high degree of [[Unsaturated fat|unsaturation]] are most susceptible to autoxidation. The best test for [[autoxidation]] (oxidative rancidity) is determination of the peroxide value. [[Peroxide]]s are intermediates in the autoxidation reaction.
Autoxidation is a [[Free radical addition|free radical reaction]] involving [[oxygen]] that leads to deterioration of fats and oils which form off-flavours and off-odours. Peroxide value, concentration of peroxide in an oil or fat, is useful for assessing the extent to which spoilage has advanced.
== Definition ==
The peroxide value is defined as the amount of peroxide oxygen per 1 [[kilogram]] of fat or oil. Traditionally this was expressed in units of [[milliequivalent]]s, although if we are using [[SI unit]]s then the appropriate option would be in [[millimole]]s per [[kilogram]] (N.B. 1 milliequivalents = 0.5 millimole; because 1 mEq of O2 =1 mmol/2=0.5 mmol of O2, where 2 is valence). <!-- See discussion page --> Note also that the unit of milliequivalent has been commonly abbreviated as mequiv or even as meq.
==Method== The peroxide value is determined by measuring the amount of [[iodine]] which is formed by the reaction of peroxides (formed in fat or oil) with [[iodide]] ion.
2 I<sup>−</sup> + H<sub>2</sub>O + HOOH -> HOH + 2OH<sup>−</sup> + I<sub>2</sub>
Note that the [[Base (chemistry)|base]] produced in this reaction is taken up by the excess of [[acetic acid]] present. The iodine liberated is titrated with [[sodium thiosulphate]].
2S<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><sup>2−</sup> + I<sub>2</sub> -> S<sub>4</sub>O<sub>6</sub><sup>2−</sup> + 2 I<sup>−</sup>
The acidic conditions (excess acetic acid) prevents formation of hypoiodite (analogous to [[hypochlorite]]), which would interfere with the reaction.
The indicator used in this reaction is a [[Starch indicator|starch solution]] where [[amylose]] forms a blue to black solution with iodine and is colourless where iodine is [[Redox titration|titrated]].
A precaution that should be observed is to add the starch indicator solution only near the [[Equivalence point|end point]] (the end point is near when fading of the yellowish iodine colour occurs) because at high iodine concentration starch is decomposed to products whose indicator properties are not entirely reversible.
==Taste==
Peroxide values of fresh oils are less than 10 milliequivalents/kg; when the peroxide value is between 30* and 40 milliequivalents/kg, a rancid taste is noticeable.
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Food safety]] [[Category:Flavors]]

revision.text:
The '''Psoriatic Arthritis Quality of Life''' (PsAQoL) measure is a disease specific [[patient-reported outcome]] measure which measures the effect that [[psoriatic arthritis]] has on a patient’s [[quality of life]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Brodszky|first=V |author2=Pentek, M |author3=Balint, PV |author4=Geher, P |author5=Hajdu, O |author6=Hodinka, L |author7=Horvath, G |author8=Koo, E |author9=Polgar, A |author10=Sesztak, M |author11=Szanto, S |author12=Ujfalussy, I |author13=Gulacsi, L|title=Comparison of the Psoriatic Arthritis Quality of Life (PsAQoL) questionnaire, the functional status (HAQ) and utility (EQ-5D) measures in psoriatic arthritis: results from a cross-sectional survey|journal=Scandinavian Journal of Rheumatology|date=August 2010|volume=39|issue=4|pages=303–309|doi=10.3109/03009740903468982|url=http://informahealthcare.com/doi/abs/10.3109/03009740903468982|accessdate=9 October 2013|pmid=20166848}}</ref>
It is a self-administered, 20-item [[questionnaire]] that takes about three minutes to complete.<ref name="mckenna">{{cite journal|last=McKenna|first=S|author2=Doward, L |author3=Whalley, D |author4=Tennant, A |author5=Emery, P |author6= Veale, D |title=Development of the PsAQoL: a quality of life instrument specific to psoriatic arthritis|journal=Annals of the Rheumatic Diseases|date=February 2004|volume=63|issue=2|pages=162–169|doi=10.1136/ard.2003.006296|pmc=1754880|pmid=14722205}}</ref> The answers are restricted to true or false.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Roussou|first=Euthalia|author2=Chopra, Sunil |author3=Ngandu, Danny Lunda |title=Phenotypic and clinical differences between Caucasian and South Asian patients with psoriatic arthritis living in North East London|journal=Clinical Rheumatology|year=2013|volume=32|pages=591–599|doi=10.1007/s10067-012-2139-5|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10067-012-2139-5|accessdate=9 October 2013|issue=5|pmid=23247553}}</ref>
== Development ==
The PsAQoL was first published in 2004 by Galen Research. The development of the measure was a joint effort between Galen Research, the [[University of Leeds]] and [[St. Vincent’s University Hospital]] in Dublin. The study was funded by the [[Arthritis Research Campaign]] in the UK.<ref name="mckenna" />
[[Qualitative research|Qualitative]] interviews were conducted with 48 patients, after which a 51-item questionnaire was created. A follow up survey with 94 patients was then conducted which reduced the items to 35. An additional 286 patients were surveyed and [[Rasch model|Rasch]] analysis was performed, which finalized the PsAQoL to 20 items.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mease|first=Philip J.|title=Measures of Psoriatic Arthritis|journal=Arthritis Care & Research|date=November 2011|volume=63|issue=S11|pages=S64–S85|doi=10.1002/acr.20577|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/acr.20577/pdf|accessdate=9 October 2013|pmid=22588772}}</ref> A high score on the PsAQoL indicates a lower quality of life.
== International Use ==
The Psoriatic Arthritis Quality of Life measure has been translated into 30 languages, other than UK English.<ref>{{cite web|title=Measures Database|url=http://www.galen-research.com/measures-database/|work=Galen-Research.com|publisher=Galen Research|accessdate=9 October 2013}}</ref> These languages include Dutch<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wink|first=Freke|author2=Arends, Suzanne |author3=McKenna, Stephen P. |author4=Houtman, Pieternella M. |author5=Brouwer, Elisabeth |author6= Spoorenberg, Anneke |title=Validity and Reliability of the Dutch Adaptation of the Psoriatic Arthritis Quality of Life (PsAQoL) Questionnaire|journal=PLoS ONE|year=2013|volume=8|issue=2|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0055912|url=http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0055912|accessdate=9 October 2013|editor1-last=Kuwana|editor1-first=Masataka|pages=e55912|pmid=23418474|pmc=3572180}}</ref> and Swedish.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Billing|first=E|author2=McKenna, SP |author3=Staun, M |author4= Lindqvist, U |title=Adaptation of the Psoriatic Arthritis Quality of Life (PsAQoL) instrument for Sweden|journal=Scandinavian Journal of Rheumatology|date=May 2010|volume=39|issue=3|pages=223–228|doi=10.3109/03009740903347975|url=http://informahealthcare.com/doi/abs/10.3109/03009740903347975|accessdate=9 October 2013|pmid=20063984}}</ref> The PsAQoL has also been utilized in [[clinical research]] studies in order to determine whether a medication or treatment is effective in treating psoriatic arthritis. If the scores on the PsAQoL change after treatment, this means that the given treatment has had an effect on quality of life. The PsAQoL has been used to evaluate [[infliximab]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Marzo-Ortega|first=Helena|author2=McGonagle, Dennis |author3=Rhodes, Laura A |author4=Tan, Ai Lyn |author5=Conaghan, Philip G |author6=O'Connor, Philip |author7=Tanner, Steven F. |author8=Fraser, Alexander |author9=Veale, Douglas |author10= Emery, Paul |title=Efficacy of infliximab on MRI-determined bone oedema in psoriatic arthritis|journal=Annals of the Rheumatic Diseases|year=2007|volume=66|pages=778–781|doi=10.1136/ard.2006.063818|url=http://ard.bmj.com/content/66/6/778.abstract|accessdate=9 October 2013|issue=6|pmid=17185324|pmc=1954680}}</ref> and [[adalimumab]].<ref>{{cite web|title=A Canadian Open-Label Study to Evaluate the Safety and Effectiveness of Adalimumab When Added to Inadequate Therapy for the Treatment of Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA) (ACCLAIM)|url=http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00427362?term=PsAQoL&rank=2|work=ClinicalTrials.gov|publisher=Abbott|accessdate=9 October 2013}}</ref>
== References ==
{{reflist}}
[[Category:Rheumatology]] [[Category:Arthritis]] [[Category:Quality of life]]

revision.text:
[[File:Sahastralinga Talav Platform.JPG|thumb|Sahastralinga Tank Platform]] '''Sahasralinga Tank''' or '''Sahasralinga Talav''' is a medieval artificial water tank in [[Patan, Gujarat]], [[India]]. It was commissioned during [[Chaulukya dynasty|Chaulukya]] (Solanki) rule, but now it is empty and in a ruined state. It is a [[Monument of National Importance]] protected by [[Archaeological Survey of India]] (N-GJ-161).
==Legend== [[Jasma Odan]], a wife of Rooda who belonged to the Od community of tank diggers, cursed [[Chaulukya dynasty|Chaulukya ruler]], [[Jayasimha Siddharaja|Siddhraj Jaisinh]] when he proposed her marriage who was captivated by her beauty. Due to the curse, the tank was not filled with water. To repeal the curse, a human sacrifice was needed. Mayo or Mahya, from lower caste Dhed community, committed self-sacrifice which resulted in water filling the tank. Jaysinh, out of gratitude, allowed his caste to stay with higher castes in town.<ref name="Ray2005">{{cite book|author=Bharati Ray|title=Women of India: Colonial and Post-colonial Periods|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aJFwK8XYQMkC&pg=PA527|date=4 October 2005|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-0-7619-3409-7|pages=527–}}</ref><ref name="Ray2009">{{cite book|author1=Bharati Ray|author2=Swati Joshi|title=Different Types of History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9x5FX2RROZgC&pg=PA374|year=2009|publisher=Pearson Education India|isbn=978-81-317-1818-6|pages=374–}}</ref><ref name="(India)1965">{{cite book|author=Gujarat (India)|title=Gujarat State Gazetteers: Rajkot District|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mSAbAAAAIAAJ|year=1965|publisher=Directorate of Government Print., Stationery and Publications, Gujarat State|page=138}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Bairam Khan is assassinated by an Afghan at Patan, 1561, Akbarnama.jpg|left|thumb|Bairam Khan is assassinated by an Afghan at Patan, 1561, Akbarnama]] Sahasralinga Tank are among the many artificial tanks built in different parts of Gujarat under the patronages of [[Jayasimha Siddharaja]] (1092-1142 AD).
[[Bairam Khan]], Akbar's tutor, while passing through Patan on his way to Mecca, was said to have been murdered after he returned from boating in this tank in 1561.
==Architecture == {{rewrite section|date=August 2014}} [[File:Water tunnels at Sahasraling Talav, Pattan.jpg|thumb|Water inlets]] [[File:Sahasraling Talav at Pattan.jpg|thumb|Platform]] [[File:Channel for Sahastralinga Talav.JPG|thumb|Channel]] [[File:Sahastralinga Talao (Patan).JPG|thumb|Ruined pillars]] [[Image:Sahastra Linga Tank, PATAN, GUJARAT, INDIA.jpg|thumb|right|Ruined pillars]]
The architecture of this tank integrated the great sense of water management and sanctity of water in Hindu religion. The tank used to receive water from a canal of the Saraswati River and had spread of about 5 km with good stone masonry embankments. There were thousand Shiva Shrines on the edge of the tank. Some remains of the same are even visible today.
One of the largest and the grandest in size is the Sahasralinga Tank. It must have been a reservoir of immense size and derived its name from the numerous little temples containing linga placed on the banks which were dismantled during the late medieval period, when a large octagonal rouza was raised on a part of its ruins. The great embankment surrounding it is of solid brick work and was faced with stone masonry forming flights of steps to the water's edge. Near the middle of the eastern embankment are the remains of the old Siva temple, comprising the basements of the pavilions together with a colonnade of forty eight pillars; it was in good condition till 16th century A.D. Towards the western end there is a rudra kupa in which water from the river Saraswati was collected and then allowed to pass into the inlet channel of the Sahasralinga Tank. This cistern is about forty meters in diameter.<ref name="Pandya2007">{{cite book|author=Kaushik Pandya|title=A journey to the glorious Gujarat|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g4MMAQAAMAAJ|year=2007|publisher=Akshara Prakashan|page=103}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Jasma Odan]] * [[Patan, Gujarat]]
==Spelling confusion== Saha'''sr'''a <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shabdkosh.com/sa/translate/sahasra/sahasra-meaning-in-Sanskrit-English|title=Sahasra}}</ref>is the correct suffix that means "a thousand", not Saha'''s'''T'''r'''a. However, it is invariably misspelled as the latter. Notice how the same suffix is spelled when it occurs in family names (example: Sahasrabuddhe<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vinaysahasrabuddhe.in/|title=Sahasrabuddhe}}</ref>) ''without'' a T. The confusion arises because the hindi letter "Sa" (स) merges with "ra" (र) and looks like "tra".
==References == {{reflist}}

{{refimprove|date=January 2011}} {{Infobox settlement | name = Sorokdo | native_name = 소록도
小鹿島 | native_name_lang = Korean | translit_lang1 = Korean | translit_lang1_type1 = Hangul | translit_lang1_info1 = 소록도 | translit_lang1_type2 = Hanja | translit_lang1_info2 = 小鹿島 | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = [[South Korea]] | subdivision_type1 = [[Regions of Korea|Region]] | subdivision_name1 = [[Jeolla]] | area_total_km2 = 4.46 | population_as_of = | population_total = 1,169 }} '''Sorokdo''' (Sorok island) is an island in [[Goheung]], [[Jeolla]], [[South Korea]]. "Sorok" means "small deer", which the island's coastline, viewed from above, is supposed to resemble. ==Travelling to Sorokdo== It takes five minutes to reach Sorokdo from Nokdong-hang (Nokdong harbor) in [[Goheung]]. As of 3 March 2009, Sorok-Daegyo (bridge) is open for traffic. ==Leper Colony== Sorokdo is the site of a [[leper colony]] with a history of [[patient abuse]] including slave labor, [[Sterilization_(medicine)|forced sterilizations]], and starvation, under both Japanese and Korean administration.{{cite news | url = http://www.thestate.com/2013/11/24/3119624/ex-leprosy-patients-return-to.html | title = Korean ex-leprosy patients return to island colony | work = The State |date = 2013-11-24 | accessdate=2013-11-24 }}{{cite news | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/sorok-island-the-last-leper-colony-462293.html | title = Sorok Island: The last leper colony | work = The State |date = 2007-08-20 | accessdate=2013-11-24 }} ==References== {{reflist}} 월간 GEO, 한센인들의 마음의 고향-소록도 기사. {{SouthKorea-geo-stub}} {{coord|34|30|N|127|07|E|source:kolossus-eswiki|display=title}} [[Category:Islands of South Korea]] [[Category:Leper colonies]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations in South Korea]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Software | name = StatsDirect | logo = | screenshot= statsdirect_logo_button.png | developer = StatsDirect Ltd | latest_release_version = 3.0.169 | latest_release_date = {{release date and age|2016|3|31}} | operating_system = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] | genre = [[Statistics|Statistical analysis]] | license = [[Proprietary software|proprietary]] | website = [http://www.statsdirect.com www.statsdirect.com] }}
'''StatsDirect''' is a [[List of statistical packages|statistical software package]] designed for biomedical, public health, and general health science uses. The second generation of the software was reviewed in general medical<ref name="Freemantle">{{cite journal|last=Freemantle|first=Nick|title=CD: StatsDirect---Statistical Software for Medical Research in the 21st Century|journal=BMJ|date=16 December 2000|volume=321|issue=7275|pages=1536|doi=10.1136/bmj.321.7275.1536}}</ref> and public health journals.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lipp|first=Alastair|title=Stats Direct|journal=Journal of Public Health|date=1 September 2002|volume=24|issue=3|pages=242|doi=10.1093/pubmed/24.3.242}}</ref>
== Features and use == StatsDirect's interface is menu driven and has editors for spreadsheet-like data and reports. The function library includes common medical statistical methdods that can be extended by users via an [[XML]]-based description that can embed calls to native StatsDirect numerical libraries, [[R (programming language)|R]] scripts, or algorithms in any of the [[.NET Framework|.NET]] languages (such as [[C Sharp (programming language)|C#]], [[Visual Basic .NET|VB.Net]], [[J Sharp|J#]], or [[F Sharp (programming language)|F#]]).<ref name="SDTech">{{cite web|url=http://www.statsdirect.com/sd3technology.aspx|title=StatsDirect Technologies|publisher=StatsDirect Ltd|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref>
Common statistical misconceptions are challenged by the interface. For example, users can perform a [[chi-square test]] on a two-by-two table, but they are asked whether the data are from a [[Cohort study|cohort (perspective)]] or [[Case-control study|case-control (retrospective)]] study before delivering the result. Both processes produce a chi-square test result but more emphasis is put on the appropriate statistic for the inference, which is the odds ratio for retrospective studies and relative risk for prospective studies.<ref>{{cite book|last=Davis|first=Cole|title=Statistical Testing in Practice with StatsDirect|year=2013|url=http://www.coledavis.org/book.html|isbn=978-1605944500}}</ref>
== Origins == Professor Iain Buchan of the [[University of Manchester]] wrote a doctoral thesis on the foundational work and is credited as creator of the software.<ref>{{cite web|last=Buchan|first=Iain Edward|title=The Development of a Statistical Computer Software Resource for Medical Research (MD Thesis)|url=http://www.statsdirect.com/thesis/md.pdf|publisher=University of Liverpool|accessdate=3 May 2014}}</ref> Buchan said he wished to address the problem of clinicians lacking the statistical knowledge to select and interpret statistical functions correctly, and often misusing software written by and for statisticians as a result.
The software debuted in 1989 as Arcus, then Arcus ProStat in 1993, both written for the DOS platform.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Adler|first=Eric|title=Arcus Pro-Stat 3 (Short Reviews)|journal=Personal Computer World|date=March 1994|pages=306|url=http://www.computinghistory.org.uk/det/690/Personal-Computer-World-March-1994/}}</ref> Arcus Quickstat for Windows followed in 1999.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Sachdev|first=Harshi|title=Arcus Quickstat (Multimedia Review)|journal=Indian Pediatrics|date=October 1999|volume=36|issue=10|pages=1075–1076|url=http://www.indianpediatrics.net/oct99-16.htm}}</ref> In 2000, an expanded version, StatsDirect, was released for Microsoft Windows.<ref name="Freemantle"/> In 2013, the third generation of this software was released, written in [[C Sharp (programming language)|C#]] for the [[.NET Framework|.NET]] platform.<ref name="SDTech"/>
StatsDirect reports embed the metadata necessary to replay calculations, which may be needed if the original data is ever updated. The reproducible report technology follows the [[Research Objects|research object]] approach for replaying in "eLabs".<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Bechhofer, Sean; Buchan, Iain; De Roure, David; Missier, Paolo; Ainsworth, John; Bhagat, Jiten; Couch, Philip; Cruickshank, Don; Delderfield, Mark; Dunlop, Ian; Gamble, Matthew; Michaelides, Danius; Owen, Stuart; Newman, David; Sufi, Shoaib; Goble, Carole|title=Why linked data is not enough for scientists|journal=Future Generation Computer Systems|volume=29|issue=2|pages=599–611|doi=10.1016/j.future.2011.08.004}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.statsdirect.com StatsDirect Home page]
{{Statistical software}}
[[Category:Statistical software]] [[Category:Windows-only software]] [[Category:Biostatistics]]

{{Infobox football biography |name=Teruki Miyamoto
宮本 輝紀 |image= |image_size= |caption= |fullname=Teruki Miyamoto |birth_date={{Birth date|1940|12|26}} |birth_place=[[Hiroshima]], [[Hiroshima Prefecture|Hiroshima]], [[Japan]] |death_date={{Death date and age|2000|2|2|1940|12|26}} |death_place=[[Kitakyushu]], [[Fukuoka Prefecture|Fukuoka]], [[Japan]] |height={{Height|m=1.71}} |position=[[Midfielder]] |currentclub= |clubnumber= |youthyears1=|youthclubs1= |years1=1959–1976|clubs1=[[Nippon Steel Yawata SC|Nippon Steel]]|caps1=138|goals1=68 |totalcaps=138|totalgoals=68 |nationalyears1=1961–1971|nationalteam1=[[Japan national football team|Japan]]|nationalcaps1=58|nationalgoals1=19 |manageryears1=1976–1979|managerclubs1=[[Nippon Steel Yawata SC|Nippon Steel]] |medaltemplates={{MedalOlympic}} {{MedalBronze|[[1968 Summer Olympics|1968 Mexico City]]|[[Football at the 1968 Summer Olympics|Team competition]]}} |club-update= |nationalteam-update= }} {{Nihongo|'''Teruki Miyamoto'''|宮本 輝紀|Miyamoto Teruki|December 26, 1940 – February 2, 2000}} was a [[Japan]]ese [[Association football|football]] player and manager. He played for [[Japan national football team|Japan national team]]. ==Club career== Miyamoto was born in [[Hiroshima]] on December 26, 1940. After graduating from high school, he joined [[Nippon Steel Yawata SC|Yawata Steel]] (later ''Nippon Steel'') in 1959. The club won [[1964 Emperor's Cup]]. In 1965, Yawata Steel joined new league [[Japan Soccer League]]. In 1967, he was elected Japanese Footballer of the Year awards. He retired in 1976. He played 138 games and scored 68 goals in the league. He was elected Best Eleven for 6 years in a row ([[1966 Japan Soccer League|1966]]-[[1971 Japan Soccer League|1971]]). ==National team career== In June 1961, Miyamoto was elected [[Japan national football team|Japan national team]] for [[1962 FIFA World Cup qualification#Asia|1962 World Cup qualification]]. At this qualification, on June 11, he debuted against [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]]. He was elected Japan for [[Football at the 1964 Summer Olympics|1964 Summer Olympics]] in [[Tokyo]] and [[Football at the 1968 Summer Olympics|1968 Summer Olympics]] in [[Mexico City]]. He played all matches at both Olympics and Japan won the bronze medal 1968 Olympics. He also played at [[Football at the 1962 Asian Games|1962]], [[Football at the 1966 Asian Games|1966]] and [[Football at the 1970 Asian Games|1970 Asian Games]]. At [[Football at the 1972 Summer Olympics – Men's qualification|1972 Summer Olympics qualification]] in 1971, Japan's failure to qualify for [[Football at the 1972 Summer Olympics|1972 Summer Olympics]]. This qualification was his last game for Japan. He played 58 games and scored 19 goals for Japan until 1971.[http://www.jfootball-db.com/en/players/miyamoto_teruki.html Japan National Football Team Database] ==Coaching career== In 1976, when Miyamoto played for [[Nippon Steel Yawata SC|Nippon Steel]], he became a playing manager. He managed until 1979. On February 2, 2000, Miyamoto died of [[heart failure]] in [[Kitakyushu]] at the age of 59. In 2006, he was elected [[Japan Football Hall of Fame]]. ==National team statistics== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" ! colspan=3 | [[Japan national football team|Japan national team]] |- !Year!!Apps!!Goals |- |[[1961 Japan national football team|1961]]||5||3 |- |[[1962 Japan national football team|1962]]||7||1 |- |[[1963 Japan national football team|1963]]||5||2 |- |[[1964 Japan national football team|1964]]||2||0 |- |[[1965 Japan national football team|1965]]||4||1 |- |[[1966 Japan national football team|1966]]||5||3 |- |[[1967 Japan national football team|1967]]||5||5 |- {{other uses}} {{Redirect|Varmints|the episode of ''Adventure Time''|Adventure Time (season 7)}} {{globalize/UK and Canada|date=February 2017}} [[File:Wild rabbit.jpg|thumb|250px|A wild rabbit – considered a [[Pest (organism)|pest]] by many farmers, due to their eating of farmer crops]]
'''Vermin''' ([[colloquialism|colloquially]] '''varmint'''<ref name="origin" /> or '''varmit''') are [[Pest (organism)|pests]] or [[nuisance animal]]s, that [[zoönosis|spread diseases]] or destroy [[crops]] or [[livestock]]. Since the term is defined in relation to human activities, which species are included vary from area to area and person to person.
The term derives from the [[Latin]] ''vermis'' ([[worm]]), and was originally used for the worm-like [[larva]]e of certain [[insect]]s, many of which infest foodstuffs.<ref>{{cite web |title=Vermin |work=Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary |publisher=Britannica Publishing |url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/vermin |accessdate=December 13, 2006}}</ref> The term ''varmint'' (and ''vermint'') has been found in sources from c. 1530–1540s.<ref name="origin">{{cite web |publisher=Dictionary.com |title=Varmint definition |accessdate=2012-01-05 |url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/Varmint?qsrc=2888|quote=Origin: 1530–40; var. of vermin}}</ref><ref>"Vermint" cited in England in 1539, ''Oxford English Dictionary', 2nd ed</ref>
== Spelling distinction == ''Varmint'' or ''varmit'' is an [[American-English]] [[colloquialism]], particularly common to the [[Eastern United States|American East]] and South-east within the nearby bordering states of the vast [[Appalachia]] region. The term describes farm pests which raid farms as opposed to those that infest farms, referring mainly to predators such as [[Free-ranging dog|feral dogs]], [[fox]]es, [[weasel]]s, and [[coyote]]s, sometimes even [[Wolf|wolves]] or rarely [[bear]]s, but also, to a lesser degree, herbivores and burrowing animals that directly damage crops and land.
Although this version of the word "vermin" is not a prevalent term in [[Standard Written English]], it is a common descriptor for certain kinds of weapons and [[pest control]] situations in the Appalachian and nearby states and the American west and south-west which have adopted terms such as ''[[varmint rifle]]'' and ''[[varmint hunting]]''.
== Scope of meanings == The term "vermin" is used to refer to a wide scope of organisms, including [[rodent]]s, [[cockroach]]es, [[termite]]s, and [[Bed bug (insect)|bed bug]]s.<ref name="Bellemore2006">{{cite book|author=Phillipa Bellemore|title=Tenants' Rights Manual: A Practical Guide to Renting in NSW|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KbTaHlWD-VoC&pg=PA66|date=November 2006 |publisher=Federation Press|isbn=978-1-86287-557-9|pages=66}}</ref>
Historically, in the 16th and 17th century, the expression also became used as a [[derogatory term]] associated with groups of persons typically plagued by vermin, namely [[beggar]]s and [[Vagrancy (people)|vagabonds]], and more generally [[Poverty|the poor]].<ref name="Raber2013">{{cite book|author=Karen Raber|title=Animal Bodies, Renaissance Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QdwAAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA26|date=24 September 2013|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press |isbn=978-0-8122-0859-7|pages=26–27}}</ref>
Disease-carrying [[rodent]]s and [[insect]]s are the usual case, but the term is also applied to larger animals—especially small [[predator]]s—typically because they consume [[Natural resource|resources]] which humans consider theirs, such as livestock and crops. Birds which eat cereal crops and fruit are an example. The American crow (''Corvus brachyrhynchos''), is widely hated by farmers because of crop depredation. [[Rock dove|Pigeons]], which have been widely introduced in urban environments, are also sometimes considered vermin. Some varieties of [[snake]]s and [[arachnid]]s may also be referred to as vermin. Vermin is also used as a term for vile people, an enemy of a state or nation, or certain ethnic groups that are considered [[wikt:subhuman|subhuman]].<ref name=origin />
== Deterioration of balance == Any species can develop into vermin if introduced into a region where there is favorable living conditions and few natural predators. In such cases, they are seen as an invasive species and humans often choose to fill the role of the [[predator]] to limit the danger to the environment. Examples of vermin include [[goat]]s on the [[Galápagos Islands]], [[rabbits in Australia]] or [[cat]]s on [[Prince Edward Islands]]. [[Rat]]s, [[mouse|mice]], and [[cockroaches]] are common urban and suburban vermin.
== Canada == Hunting laws and definitions vary by province in Canada.{{fact|date=December 2017}}
== United Kingdom == Under Tudor "vermin laws", many creatures were seen as competitors for the produce of the countryside and bounties were paid by the parish for their carcasses. The declaration of the [[red kite]] as vermin led to its decline to the point of extirpation in the UK by the 20th century. However, the red kite is being reintroduced by the trans-location of breeding pairs from other parts of Europe.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/reviews/silent-fields-by-roger-lovegrove-441401.html|title=Book Review: Silent Field, By Roger Lovegrove: songbirds versus shotguns|last=McCarthy|first=Michael|date=23 March 2007|work=The Independent |accessdate=2009-07-07}}</ref>
== Animals == Vermin types can also include ferrets, stoats, sables, rats, and occasionally foxes. == See also == * [[Parasite]] * [[Pest (organism)]] * [[Varmint hunting]] * [[Weed]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
